newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta call money volatile, bond prices up.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta call money volatile, bond prices up.

text.p: Jakarta call money declined to 13.5/14.0 percent from an early high of 16.0 percent on Tuesday morning, with bond prices continuing to rise, dealers said.
One state bank dealer said fears of large weekly tax payments due Tuesday semed to keep operators nervous.
She said some banks seemed to have higher tax obligations due to the approaching fiscal year end on March 31.
Another local bank dealer said worry over tight conditions in the afternoon prevented operators from unloading rupiah, raising overnight money to a high of 16.0 percent.
"But a relatively large commercial demand on dollars seems to have helped generate rupiah and trigger other operators to drop their rupiah retained earlier," the dealer said.
Dealers said longer-term rates were stable and the central bank kept interest rates for bilateral papers (SBIs) stable.

The bank offered three days SBIs at seven percent, 6-7 day at 8.5 percent, 8-10 day at 9.5 percent, 13-17 day at 10.0 percent, 20-24 day at 10.5 percent, one-month at 11.5 percent, three-, six- and 12-month at 12.25, 12.50 and 12.75 percent.
One- and three-month money were quoted at 12.50/12.75 and 13.25/13.50 percent, respectively.
Bond prices continued their uptrend averaging 25 to 100 basis points, keeping further pressure on the average yield.

One bond dealer said the yield of the benchmark PLN V/A bond declined to 15.37 percent at its last traded price of 105.25 percent, approaching the grey market yield of the 400 billion rupiah Astra International bonds.
He said the grey market price of Astra hovered at 100.5 percent, reflecting a yield of about 15.35 percent.
"There is some anticipation the benchmark yield of PLN might head towards the 15.0 percent level," the dealer said, adding that it would be equivalent to 106.5 percent.
The average overnight interbank rate on Monday was 15.02 percent, compared with 21.52 percent on Friday.
